_prev_prog_3.Description: Anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant in this edible oils processing, manufacturing and storage facility. The ammonia refrigeration system contains various pieces of equipment including  compressors, pressure vessels,  evaporators, condensers, ice builders, heat exchangers, associated valves & piping systems, and ammonia release dilution tanks. The refrigeration system is internal to the facility with the exeption of the evaporators that are roof mounted and the fire department valve control box located on the Eastern wall of the facility. The facility converts vegetable oils and other ingredients into margarines, spreads, shortenings and other edible oil products.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Stationary Source 



As part of our efforts, we have adopted emergency response policies which are relevant to the ammonia refrigeration system.  



Our policies include:



A documented Emergency Action Plan to ensure the Facility appropriately responds in the event of an accidental ammonia release (including required drills to ensure the preparedness of VF employees) and several written standard operating procedures (SOPs), including SOPs for Ammonia Release Reporting, Incident Investigations, and a Contractor Environmental Health and Safety (EHS) management program.  As part of our continuous improvement efforts, the Facility reviews the effectiveness of these procedures on an annual basis.



We have developed and implemented an Emergency Response Program.  The program is documented in the Site's Emergency Action Plan (EAP). The purpose of the Emergency Response Program is to specify how Facility personnel will respond to emergencies of: fire, ammonia release, other chemical release, bomb or other criminal activity threat, severe weather, severe injury or illness, and power outage. 



The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The only regulated substance triggering the need for this RMP is ammonia.



Ventura Foods, Ontario Facility, operates a closed-loop ammonia refrigeration system.  Because the anhydrous ammonia inventory exceeds the federal and state thresholds, a Risk Management Plan (RMP) is required. The Facility recognizes that this system presents certain risks to the safety of its employees and neighbors, as well as to the environment, and that procedures are required to identify and analyze those risks, and then to use that analysis to minimize the risks.  In addition, the Facility recognizes that, as an operator of this system, we have obligations.  



The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Steps



The key components of the

Facility's RMP include:



? The Facility has adopted a zero tolerance policy for accidental ammonia releases.  To implement this policy, the Facility has identified potential hazards and implemented operating procedures and other controls (engineering and administrative). We periodically evaluate the effectiveness of these controls in a manner specifically designed to enable continuous improvement of the ammonia refrigeration management program.



? The Facility has prepared and adopted a Contractor EHS Management Program.  Key to this program is the reinforcement of the need for requisite contractor qualifications and training, as well as improved company procedures to track and document contractor qualifications and performance.

    

? As part of its implementation of the RMP, the Facility has Mechanical Integrity procedures to ensure that identified risks associated with ammonia refrigeration equipment are properly assessed and managed as part of regular maintenance practices pursuant to manufacturer and industry standards.  As part of its continuous improvement efforts, the Facility will review the effectiveness of these procedures on an annual basis. 

 

? VF has trained and educated all departments of the Ontario Facility in their respective responsibilities for risk identification and reduction.  In particular, the partnership between the Maintenance Department, EHS Department and Management has been emphad to ensure cohesive and effective implementation of all EHS program requirements.



? The Facility has reviewed and revised its hazardous material release reporting program (an important sub-part of its Emergency Action Plan) in order to ensure timely and accurate reporting to all responsible agencies.



? As part of the development of the RMP, the Facility has re-evaluated likely areas of risk and revised this RMP to ensure that risk identification, and associated hazard reduction planning, is both expansive and regularly updated.  The Facility will

engage in routine evaluation of risks to ensure continuous improvement of its accidental ammonia release prevention program.



? Training is one of the keys to proper employee and contractor compliance with RMP requirements.  Consistent with fact, the Facility has revised and renewed employee and contractor training as part of the RMP improvement and implementation process.



? This RMP has been designed using the Plan - Do - Check - Act (PDCA) model.  This approach was adopted to enable continuous improvement of the Facility's system for accidental ammonia release prevention.



Five-Year Accident History



In the last five years, the Facility has not had any accidental ammonia releases that have resulted in deaths, injuries or significant property damage on site; or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage. 



Emergency Response Program



Our emergency planning and response plan is outlined in our Risk Management Plan. It covers the following:



? Specific actions to be taken in the event of a release



? Accidental Release Reporting



? Information on Emergency Health Care



? Emergency Response Training



? Other Federal or State Emergency Plans

  - CalOSHA  - 8 CCR 5189

  - EPA (Right to Know) Section 304

  - Clean Air Act Section 112(r)(7)



? History of Review of the Emergency Action Plan 

  - Revision table to explain any change to the program

  - Document annual review of the program 



Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



The Facility's management system is designed to ensure accidental ammonia releases are prevented.  The PHA is designed to expose possible release scenarios and determine if we have sufficient safeguards in place to prevent such an event. 



The following recommendations, from our most recent PHA, are scheduled and assigned for completion:



? Perform an alarm survey and ensure NH3 alarms are heard in all area of the facility. Determine if gaps exist and

take action to close the gaps.



? Add a task procedure to the Compressor SOPs for adding and draining oil. 



? Emergency ventilation system in our compressor room is being upgraded.



? Add an additional safeguard which verifies actual air flow or motor starter failure, using the existing HMI that is located outside the entry door, with the ventilation upgrade mentioned above. 



? Consider the addition of a second access/egress from margarine room roof; cooler roofs and main roof



? Improve the housekeeping standards in the compressor room. Add a monthly PM to the system.



? Perform and document lighting survey in compressor room to determine if additional emergency lighting is needed



? Add a five year PM to replace the suction control valve diaphragm on Line 47 to our program.
